awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Development and Evaluation of a Service-Learning Focused Chemistry Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine the value of a fully integrated service-learning-oriented chemistry curriculum.  Specifically, this project will focus on students' gains as they engage in service-learning throughout their undergraduate chemistry curriculum.  Service-learning provides students with opportunities for authentic engagement with their communities, and there is evidence that it can lead to increased student confidence and competence in the sciences.  Project objectives include: 1) developing and implementing a fully integrated, service-learning-oriented chemistry curriculum at Saint Joseph's College; 2) evaluating the specific benefits of this curriculum as students build on their evolving roles as community-engaged scientists; and 3) creating and disseminating a new service-learning-oriented chemistry instructional model called "Chemistry for the Community."  The project not only has the potential to enhance the chemistry curriculum at Saint Joseph's College, but could also provide benefits to community partners involved in the project.  These partners include younger students in K-12 classes who will have increased opportunities to actively engage in STEM activities that may foster interest and self-confidence in STEM.

The project will develop and disseminate the Chemistry for the Community model based on information gained through the implementation of the multi-year curriculum at Saint Joseph's College.  Toward this end, the project will generate new knowledge about service learning and its advantages using the following methodologies.  First, the implementation will include a control vs. treatment group assessment in the first year.  Second, multi-year implementation will enable rigorous quantification of the accrued benefits across multiple semesters.  Third, the use of SPIRES (Self-determination, Purpose, Identity, and Engagement in Science) as an assessment tool will provide new knowledge regarding scientific identity and professional disposition in the service learning modality.  Finally, a focused, sequential series of dissemination platforms (online social networks, symposium, and workshop) will help other institutions implement Chemistry for the Community, while materials developed through this project will be made available via a dedicated project website to reach institutions beyond those directly participating in the dissemination activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Chemistry for the Community engaged students in community service projects as part of multiple chemistry lab classes across an entire curriculum. By implementing one project each semester, students encountered at least five opportunities during a four-year program. The project was created by chemistry professors Emily Lesher and Yi Jin Gorske at St. Joseph's College in Standish, Maine. In parallel, a research group at the University of New Hampshire Chemistry Department, including Professor Christopher Bauer, research associate Dr. Kathleen Bowe, and graduate student Alexa Green, carried out an assessment of student and faculty experiences. First-year chemistry students taught chemistry lessons at a local middle school, organic chemistry students shared chemistry concepts with local high school students, and analytical chemistry students analyzed water in a local lake for reporting to community and environmental organizations. The project was able gather student perceptions during periods when the community interactions were face-to-face and also by video conference during pandemic restrictions. In fact, pandemic shut-downs offered an important contrasting case in which students described what valuable experiences they were missing when not face-to-face.

The project has intellectual merit in two ways. First, the results provide guidance on how to weave public service directly into a STEM curriculum such that it becomes a recurring and reinforcing component of learning science. Second, students report learning chemistry more strongly and point to important communication skills and confidence gained in having to demonstrate their knowledge. This engagement helped students feel that they belonged to the scientific community and improved their feelings of competence, while feelings of boredom and frustration with chemistry declined. It is anticipated that this growth in affiliation, confidence, and skills would lead to students persisting in their major and continuing to serve their communities after graduation.

From a broader perspective, this project demonstrates that service learning need not be considered only an add-on extra-curricular activity but can be an important driver for content learning and skill development. Students cited that they loved the opportunity to expand their skill set beyond the norm for chemistry lab, like working with their peers and speaking in front of a live audience. When projects could not be completed (pandemic shut-downs interfered with some of the planned activities), students were sad that they did not get to see themselves finish and gain the confidence that they could be successful in teaching a chemistry topic to someone else. Students overwhelmingly preferred in-person events for their own benefit and to the benefit of the community members they were working with. At the same time, the community had the opportunity for continuing associations with the local college.

Clear guidelines on group efforts and community interactions prevented negative peer interactions that may spoil an otherwise positive learning experience. Students frequently perceived only a single group benefitting from their projects (i.e., the middle school students), when multiple parties (the middle school and the middle school teachers) were also benefitting from having the projects take place. By making these broader associations clear, students have a higher chance of recognizing the full benefits to themselves, their peers, and their community. With proper design and planning, curriculum-embedded community activities can be an excellent way to provide professional experiences not normally incorporated in science classes, like improving public speaking skills and other transferable skills valued by employers. This structure may also help increase the retention of students in science career paths, while also helping them become a scientist who enjoys serving their local community.
